notAlone.title: You're Not Alone in This Journey üíô
notAlone.content: Parenting through puberty can feel challenging, but you're doing great! This app provides expert guidance, resources, and tools to help you support your child with confidence and understanding. Together, we can make this transition smooth and positive.

welcome.title: Welcome, Dear Parents! üíù
welcome.subtitle: We understand how challenging and beautiful it can be to guide your child through puberty. You're here because you care deeply, and that's what matters most.
welcome.heartfeltMessage: Every parent wants the best for their child. Puberty is one of life's most significant transitions, and your support can make all the difference. This app was created with love to help you understand, communicate, and connect with your child during these crucial years. You're not just a parent - you're their guide, their safe space, and their hero. We're here to support YOU as you support them.

suggestions.q1: How can I talk to my child about puberty?
suggestions.q2: What are normal emotional changes during puberty?
suggestions.q3: How do I handle my child's mood swings?
suggestions.q4: When should I be concerned about my child's development?

responses.greeting: Hello! I'm so glad you're here. As a parent, you're taking an important step by seeking information and support. How can I help you today?
responses.puberty: Puberty is a natural transition that typically begins between ages 8-14. It involves physical changes (growth spurts, body development), emotional changes (mood swings, new feelings), and social changes (shifting friendships, increased independence). Every child's journey is unique. The best thing you can do is maintain open communication, be patient, and provide a safe space for questions. What specific aspect would you like to know more about?
responses.emotions: Emotional changes during puberty are completely normal and caused by hormonal shifts. Your child might experience mood swings, increased sensitivity, or new feelings they don't understand. Here's how to help: 1) Validate their feelings, 2) Create safe spaces for conversation, 3) Be patient with outbursts, 4) Teach healthy coping strategies, 5) Watch for signs of serious depression or anxiety. Remember, this phase passes, and your steady support makes all the difference.
responses.communication: Talking to your child about puberty works best when you: 1) Start conversations early and keep them ongoing, 2) Use age-appropriate language, 3) Be honest and factual, 4) Share your own experiences if comfortable, 5) Listen more than you talk, 6) Create judgment-free zones, 7) Use resources like books or apps together. The key is making it normal, not a one-time awkward talk. Would you like specific conversation starters?
responses.friends: Social dynamics shift dramatically during puberty. Your child may: change friend groups, feel peer pressure, become more private, or struggle with fitting in. Support them by: keeping communication open, meeting their friends, teaching them about healthy friendships, respecting their growing independence while maintaining boundaries, and being available when they need you. Remember, some friend drama is normal and helps them learn important social skills.
responses.body: Physical changes during puberty include: growth spurts, body shape changes, voice deepening (especially in boys), breast development (in girls), body hair growth, skin changes (acne), increased sweating, and reproductive development. These changes happen at different rates for everyone. Help your child by: explaining what to expect, providing necessary hygiene products, respecting their privacy, and normalizing the changes. If you notice anything concerning, consult a pediatrician.
responses.school: School can become more challenging during puberty due to physical discomfort, emotional distractions, and social pressures. Support your child by: maintaining routines, helping with organization, staying in touch with teachers, creating study-friendly environments, balancing academics with rest, and watching for signs of serious stress or bullying. Remember, some grade fluctuation is normal during this transition.
responses.privacy: This app is completely private and secure. All information stays on your device. We don't collect, track, or share any data. No accounts needed. No external servers. Your family's journey is yours alone. You can use this app with complete confidence that your privacy is protected.
responses.help: I'm here to provide general guidance and support. I can help with: understanding puberty stages, communication strategies, emotional support tips, activity suggestions, and general parenting questions. However, for medical concerns, mental health issues, or serious behavioral problems, please consult with healthcare professionals, therapists, or counselors. Your pediatrician is always your best resource for health-related questions.
responses.games: Our interactive games help your child learn about puberty in a fun, pressure-free way! The Memory Game builds familiarity with puberty concepts, the Quiz Game tests knowledge in an engaging format, and the Timeline Game helps understand development stages. Playing together can open doors for natural conversations. Check out the 'Games for Kids' section!
responses.diary: The diary feature allows your child to track their moods and feelings privately. This helps them: understand emotional patterns, express themselves safely, develop self-awareness, and have a record to look back on. You can encourage use without invading privacy. If they want to share entries with you, that's their choice. The diary is stored locally on the device.
responses.thanks: You're very welcome! Remember, you're doing an amazing job just by being here and caring enough to learn. Your child is lucky to have a parent like you. Feel free to ask anything else!
responses.default: That's a great question! While I may not have a specific answer programmed for that, I can offer general guidance: 1) Trust your instincts as a parent, 2) Keep communication open with your child, 3) Consult healthcare professionals for medical concerns, 4) Remember that every child develops differently, 5) Be patient with yourself and your child. Is there something specific I can help clarify?

growth.title: Growth Spurts
growth.description: You'll grow taller! This happens at different times for everyone.

bodyShape.title: Body Shape Changes
bodyShape.description: Your body will develop new curves and proportions as you mature.

voice.title: Voice Changes
voice.description: Your voice may deepen or change in pitch - this is totally normal!

skin.title: Skin Changes
skin.description: You might get acne or oily skin. Good hygiene helps manage this.

hair.title: Hair Growth
hair.description: New hair will grow in different places on your body.

odor.title: Body Odor
odor.description: You'll start to sweat more. Using deodorant becomes important!

mood.title: Mood Swings
mood.description: Your emotions might feel like a rollercoaster - that's normal!

interests.title: New Interests
interests.description: You might develop new hobbies, interests, and passions.

independence.title: Independence
independence.description: You'll want more privacy and independence from family.

relationships.title: Relationships
relationships.description: Friendships and social connections become more important.

awareness.title: Self-Awareness
awareness.description: You'll think more about who you are and who you want to be.

confidence.title: Confidence
confidence.description: Building confidence takes time - be patient with yourself!
